'By the winter of T.A. 2799, King Thráin and his great reckoning-host, the Haban'akkâ, had made camp at Amdân, the ancient threshold of the kingdom of Khazad-dûm. It had been a long journey, for they had made a wide march around Lórien and come up from the south, treading the old stones of the Great-way.

'All through Amdân, Dwarves of the Seven Houses grew restless. I, like all of the Iron-folk, were camped near to the House of Thráin.

'Although few of us knew it at the time, it was to be the eve of battle.'
Find and rally with the Iron-folk in Amdân
Dáin can be found among the Iron-folk at Amdân.\n\nYou should talk to Dáin.
The Iron-folk can be found in the centre of Amdân at Azanulbizar.
As you walk among the Iron-folk, you catch sight of your friend Dáin
Dáin can be found among the Iron-folk at Amdân.\n\nYou should talk to Dáin.
Dáin can be found among the Iron-folk at Amdân.\n\nYou should talk to Dáin.
Talk to Dáin and attend the 'Council of the Seven'
Hermáth Stormhammer steps aside, allowing you to experience the Battle of Azanulbizar as he once did.

'Alas, such are the disadvantages of being the grandson of the Lord of the Iron Hills!\n\n'But you, my friend... I suspect you could pass among the others in this great Haban’akkâ without a second glance, even with that hammer of yours!'
In the distance, you see the Haban'akkâ of Thráin encamped at Amdân
As you leaf through the pages of Hermáth Stormhammer's account of the Sixth War of the Dwarves and Orcs, you pause at the volume containing a description of the Battle of Azanulbizar.
As you sift through the first few pages of Hermáth Stormhammer's account of the Sixth War of the Dwarves and Orcs, you notice the author has written a foreword.

'Hermáth, my friend! I was beginning to think we lost you on the Great-way!'

Dáin embraces you warmly.

'It is hard to believe that we are here at last. I have read the stories of old Azanulbizar, but none could describe it in such detail.

'It seems fitting that this war should end where it began, don't you think?

'And if what I have heard is true, we will not have to sit idle for much longer!'
